results.title: Cattle country
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada”.
The soil of the foothills of the Rocky Mountains (North America) is ideal for pasture, and the climate is excellently suited to cattle-raising. Modern methods of protecting cattle during winter, how they are treated for warble-fly, methods of breeding, spring migration to fresh grazing lands, mustering for market, and shipping away for sale, are studied on this film of Canadian cattle raising. No credits available.

results.title: [Melbourne]
results.brief_description: An amateur film shot in Melbourne around 1935 which includes: footage of school children and gardeners in the Treasury and Fitzroy Gardens; a glimpse of traffic and a No. 13 tram in the city; construction work at the Shrine of Rememberance.

results.title: A Day at the Ascot Vale School No 2608
results.brief_description: Portrays the outdoor life at a school in the 1920s. Shows school dress, assembly, physical training, organised dancing and games. Junior Red Cross activities, Mothers Club and School Committee.

results.title: Basically Black
results.brief_description: Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program written and performed by an all-Indigenous cast, this groundbreaking program tackled racism and white paternalism through humour.

constellations_primary.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_primary.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.description: “Good morning, I am a human being,” Bindi Williams tells the audience during an opening skit of Basically Black (1973). Evolving from the newly established National Black Theatre’s stage production, Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program performed by an all-Indigenous cast and led by Blak writers, this groundbreaking program tackled serious issues, like racism and white paternalism, through humour. Despite being well received for its biting satire and commentary, the show didn’t air beyond its premiere. It later emerged that it was considered too political and provocative for the ABC, who had censored parts of the script.
description_for_label: “Good morning, I am a human being,” Bindi Williams tells the audience during an opening skit of Basically Black (1973). Evolving from the newly established National Black Theatre’s stage production, Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program performed by an all-Indigenous cast and led by Blak writers, this groundbreaking program tackled serious issues, like racism and white paternalism, through humour. Despite being well received for its biting satire and commentary, the show didn’t air beyond its premiere. It later emerged that it was considered too political and provocative for the ABC, who had censored parts of the script.

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmão Film Collection]
results.material_description:
30 x reels 8mm film
Super 8mm and regular 8mm film collection, anotated list of content provided by donor see documents references window.
results.brief_description:
Kirsty Sword Gusmao AO is and Australian-East Timorese activist who served as the First Lady of East Timor from 2002 until 2007. She was married to Xanana Gusmao, Prime Minister and former President of Timor-Leste, now residing in Coburg, Melbourne. A collection of 8mm home movies including:
Sword family life, including holidays in the 1970s
Fictional student films from Eaglehawk Primary, north of Bendigo
Melbourne scenes inlcuding Tullamarine Airport
School camp
Bendigo Show
Hanging Rock excursion
Moonee Ponds
Indonesia - Denpasar
Fellowship trip to the USA

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

Selected highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:49:00 - Title card Story ‘The Bear’
00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’
